original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished: I just can't believe another week has flown by so quickly. Yesterday, I had the opportunity to drive by the new house, and I was thrilled to see that the front window was adorned with a beautiful arrangement of boxes. I'm beyond excited to finally receive the keys at the closing, and we're all set to finalize the process by next Wednesday. I was up until 3 00 am last night, engrossed in a movie marathon with Bethany. It's been a while since we've had a movie night, but it seems like there's been a lot of movie-watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown of what we watched  last night, we saw thirteen, a film that every mother of a teenager should see. It exceeded my expectations in terms of its quality and impact. Then, we watched Gigli, which lived up to its reputation as being a subpar film. We had to see it for ourselves, as the media's reviews were largely accurate.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished: Summer television used to be a barren landscape, plagued by reruns and a lack of engaging programming. However, the recent television season has brought a welcome respite, with not one, but two captivating new shows that have consumed my attention for the past week. Among the plethora of programming options, I stumbled upon a show that defies all logic and convention. 'Blow Out' is a concept that appears to have zero representation from the LGBTQ+ community, yet I found myself inexplicably drawn to it. The show revolves around hairstylist Jonathan Antin, who seeks to expand his wildly popular West Hollywood salon to Beverly Hills. Initially, I wouldn't have given it a second thought, but a chance encounter with Jonathan, whose self-absorption and monotone demeanor are equally captivating, has piqued my interest. While perusing the channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan standing in an empty space on Rodeo Drive, proclaiming in a public voice, 'I am going to build here the greatest salon

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished: My shoulder, unfortunately, has been afflicted with tendonitis, specifically the tendonitis of my right shoulder, which is located under my shoulder blade. The condition becomes increasingly debilitating when I engage in excessive arm movements, particularly when using a mouse on a computer, as I was doing during a marathon session of website updates and online work. As a result, I'm currently struggling to muster the strength to perform even the simplest tasks, including drawing, due to the excruciating pain. The lack of restful sleep has only exacerbated my discomfort, leaving me feeling rather miserable at the moment. However, I'm optimistic that I will eventually recover and regain my usual energy levels. I'm also relieved to report that my mother's surgery went smoothly, and her eyesight has shown some improvement, allowing her to perceive fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Although she still faces challenges with her vision, I'm hopeful that she will eventually regain her full visual acuity.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished: As I attempted to do laundry with the kids in tow today, I was struck by how quickly the simplest tasks can become overwhelming. I was also pleasantly surprised by the kindness of strangers, who were sweet to me for no apparent reason other than their genuine desire to be kind. It wasn't as if they were trying to solicit something in return; they simply wanted to be friendly. I had a moment where I had to deal with a drooling child, and I was wearing my designated 'wash-day' outfit. Furthermore, I'm not sure I'll ever feel the need to bathe again anytime soon, so there was no real incentive to rush through the process. As I'm doing two things simultaneously, I'm writing this post and watching a collection of videos at my desk in my room.

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished: It's 11 14 pm MST, and I'm currently in my bedroom, tackling the task of repairing the personal computer of my job's personnel director. While I don't mind lending a helping hand, I often find myself pondering the blurred lines between being a good Samaritan and being taken advantage of. As I've spent the last couple of weeks burning the midnight oil, I had been looking forward to an early night's rest, but it seemed more practical to return the computer to its rightful owner rather than keeping it hostage in my bedroom. *laughs* It seems the weary are destined for no rest. This evening, I found myself re-watching Joe Schmo 2 for the umpteenth time.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished: I'd like to take a moment to refresh my memory - what was the topic I was discussing before this? As a continuation in the 'Is This a Date?' saga, I must admit that after our peculiar lunch, my confidence was shaken, causing me to forget to share an important aspect of the story with you all. Prior to Pat's arrival at lunch, Dustan began discussing Pat's endearing qualities and his efforts to find a compatible partner for him. As I listened intently and nodded along, I began to realize that our conversation was veering more towards finding the perfect match for Dustan than engaging in meaningful dialogue with a stranger over a casual gathering. I excused myself to the restroom, caught a glimpse of my reflection in the mirror, and then posed an introspective question to myself  Am I being pawned off to the other party? Is this the new trajectory of our relationship?

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: I implore everyone to cultivate mindfulness before taking action. I believe it would be beneficial if each and every individual in the world would take a moment to reflect before rising from their bed in the morning, making a commitment to maintain this introspective state throughout the day. If they are not prepared to do so, I would suggest that they reconsider their decision and return to the comfort of their bed, surrendering to a restful slumber. I am frustrated by the prevalence of thoughtless actions. While I am not the most erudite individual, I believe it is reasonable to address the careless decisions made by some. Let us focus on specific instances of this phenomenon, and we can reserve further discussion for another time. What do you think?

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished: The two major issues with the scenario outlined in my previous post are  1. While the Bush administration's economic stimulus package has indeed boosted the economy, it has done so in a misguided manner. Robert Rubin, the former Treasury Secretary, recently told NPR's Marketplace that the same stimulus effect could have been achieved without the long-term debt burden by implementing targeted, temporary tax cuts that would primarily benefit low- and middle-income individuals. The mere mention of his name is music to our ears. Quickly, I can think of one Bush administration cabinet official who would have the gravitas to match Rubin's expertise  Paul O'Neill, the former Treasury Secretary. I still have a nagging feeling it will come to me... 2. We cannot afford to give the Republicans control only in wartime, as they have cleverly concocted an endless, global 'War on Terror' that has led to an unwinnable quagmire.

original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished: Do you ever find yourself lost in thought, pondering the intricacies of existence while sitting in a classroom, feeling suffocated by the monotony of a 2.5-hour class in any subject? Like when you're stuck in math class, feeling utterly disconnected from the world outside, and you suddenly become acutely aware of the sheer absurdity of being alive. The realization hits you with the profound thought  that you're trapped in a never-ending cycle of boredom, stuck in a never-ending loop of monotony. And it's not just the math class; any subject can be reduced to this soul-sucking, mind-numbing experience. It's the sheer cruelty of being forced to sit through an extended period of time, devoid of any sense of purpose or fulfillment. Who in their right mind would ever design such a system, where students are subjected to such an inhumane treatment? It's almost as if they're intentionally trying to suck the life out of us, leaving us as empty husks of our

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished: I have come to the realization that my days of monopoly are behind me, and I have vowed to never again place my hands on that particular game piece. Tonight, I was defeated by a small margin and won the Farqu game, possibly due to my opponent's departure after a few short hours and my desire to ensure he felt good on his final night here. Despite the outcome, I must admit that the story cannot compare to the Texas-sized headache I am currently experiencing. I have taken some Aleve, and I must say that it is doing the trick. All I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation. Your telephone is the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck, which I found particularly frustrating at the drive-in.

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. First off i have to say that camp was awesome and even better than i could have expected. God's been doing so much stuff in my life lately and it's just awesome. I've sort of turned over a new leaf i guess, but anyway's back to the beginning. We arrived at the twiggs' house on friday evening and we stayed until we left for camp on monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, walmart and watched movies.
polished: It's been a long and eventful day today. We embarked on a journey back home from Indiana, and as a result, I'm not sure I'll have the time or energy to write about everything that's been happening in my life lately. However, I must start by expressing my enthusiasm for the incredible experience I had at camp. It was truly amazing and exceeded my expectations. I've undergone a significant transformation, and I'm excited to share the details with you. We arrived at the Twiggs' residence on Friday evening and stayed until our departure on Monday. The majority of our activities consisted of visiting the fair, attending church, a parade, shopping at Walmart, and watching movies. It's been an incredible journey, and I'm grateful for all the wonderful experiences I've had recently.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished: As I bid farewell to the warmth of summer, I'm left with a mix of emotions as I prepare for my last day of vacation. I have a dentist appointment scheduled for 9 00 AM, which I'm not particularly thrilled about, but I'm willing to get it over with before diving into the demands of my surgery rotation. As a perfectionist, I thrive on excelling in everything I do, but starting anew can be daunting. I'm feeling a sense of trepidation, nervousness, and apprehension, which is only amplified by the uncertainty of the unknown. I've often joked with my friend Cassie that I'll be the only one on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight, but in reality, I'm not looking forward to being a pawn in this new game. As I embark on this new chapter, I'm left with a sense of trepidation, wondering what lies ahead.

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Renowned scholar Arun Shourie draws attention to the prescient warning issued by the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh, dating back to 1996, regarding the looming threat of a 'Third Islamic State' emerging in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, the former Director of the Intelligence Bureau and current Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had previously sounded the alarm in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times. Shourie poses a pertinent question  does the revelation that Rajeswar, rather than himself or Mr. Advani, was the author of these warnings lend credibility to the predictions, or does it instead lead one to conclude that Rajeswar is a closet communalist, thereby disqualifying him from continuing as Governor of Uttar Pradesh?

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished: I've been overcome with an overwhelming sense of exhaustion for the past two days. I've been plagued by debilitating fatigue, feeling as though I'm running on empty. Last night, I returned home and collapsed onto my bed, only stirring when my mother's voice pierced the darkness around 8 30 pm. As I slowly came to, I was disoriented and disoriented, struggling to discern the time or date. For a few disorienting moments, it was just my mother's gentle voice in the darkness, and I was grappling with the harsh reality. I find myself wondering why I'm feeling so drained... The morning brought a welcome respite, with a gentle drizzle falling from the sky. Although I'm told it's been raining continuously for the past three days in Calcutta.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished: Last night was a particularly disheartening experience. I had to discard the sweater I was painstakingly knitting, having invested about 14 inches of effort. The yarn, which was worth approximately $10, had unfortunately become too knotted and unruly by the time I reached the armholes, causing the mohair to become entangled as I continued knitting. The yarn broke frequently, and I found it challenging to frogging (ripping out rows) effectively. I was on the verge of losing my temper, which is unusual for me, as I usually manage to keep my frustration in check. In the end, I simply became exasperated and opted to abandon the project, opting instead to indulge in a more relaxing activity, such as listening to the second season of Sex and the City, which I thoroughly enjoyed. Although I didn't derive the satisfaction I had hoped for from completing the sweater, I did gain a valuable lesson from the experience.

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: In our recent class discussion, we delved into the assigned reading for the week, specifically Edward S. Casey's seminal work, "Getting Back into Place  Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World." The first chapter, "Implacement," and the subsequent "Displacement," offer a thought-provoking exploration of the concept of time as the dominant force shaping our contemporary world and culture. Casey skillfully argues that our society's emphasis on time as the situating force has led to a disconnection from the notion of place as the central axis of our cultural identity. He posits that by reconceptualizing place as the foundation of culture, we can cultivate a more grounded and community-driven existence. This reading has been the most compelling thus far in our course, and I must admit that it has left a lasting impression on me.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.
polished: As we indulge in the delightful experience of freeze pops, it's essential to acknowledge the unconventional ingredients used to achieve their vibrant colors. However, this curiosity may lead to a peculiar phenomenon, where one's life becomes slightly unconventional. While giggling is an excellent way to cope with the unexpected, one cannot help but wonder what would have transpired if we had not consumed those pops earlier. As we found ourselves in front of a closed bar, we stumbled upon an office-supplies catalogue that had been delivered to our doorstep. To our surprise, this ordinary catalogue held the key to a lifetime of extraordinary deals. Among the numerous offers, we discovered a few remarkable ones  purchase 36 permanent marker pens and receive a stunt kite as a bonus, or buy 30 lever arch files and get a barbecue as a delightful surprise.

original: Currently listening to: the little drummer boy by stevan pasero ...and now my post... Senate republicans okay, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations wankathon last week? i know i didn't. Well, okay - i did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was perpetrated by republicans who, pissed off that democrats wouldn't roll over and nominate four of bush's nutjob justices, were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day cry-fest. Never mind the fact that the democrats have already approved 168 of bush's judicial nominees - nooo, that's not good enough for the power-mad republicans who are for some reason laboring under the misapprehension they have a huge mandate for this kind of nonsense.
polished: I am currently listening to the iconic composition 'The Little Drummer Boy' by Stevan Pasero. Meanwhile, I must admit that I found myself tuning in to the 39-hour Senate session on judicial nominations last week, despite my initial reluctance. The spectacle was a colossal waste of time, orchestrated by Republicans who were frustrated that Democrats wouldn't simply rubber-stamp four of President Bush's nominees, a move they believed would yield political capital. However, this ignores the fact that Democrats have already confirmed 168 of Bush's judicial appointments. The Republicans' true motivation appears to be a misguided notion that they have a mandate for this type of political posturing, which is far from the case.

original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished: This weekend was a truly exceptional experience. Following a prolonged hiatus, I dedicated a significant amount of time to indulging in a literary marathon, devoting myself to the world of reading. I devoured three captivating novels - Bruce Sterling's 'Heavy Weather', Larry Niven's 'World of Ptavvs', and Octavia Butler's 'Parable of the Sower'. 'Heavy Weather' transported me to a dystopian near-future United States ravaged by the devastating effects of global warming and societal chaos. Although the novel was expertly crafted, with a well-paced narrative and vividly rendered characters, I must admit that I didn't find myself deeply invested in the story or its protagonists. The novel was enjoyable, but it lacked a profound emotional resonance, leaving me with a sense of mild satisfaction rather than a lasting impression.

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished: The first week back from practicum was a challenging experience, but it wasn't until the second week that the dust began to settle and the true extent of the post-practicum trauma became apparent. The aftermath of this experience has been a sobering realization, as I've come to understand that it's not just an individual issue, but rather a widespread problem that affects many students. Fortunately, a meeting with the course coordinator helped me to unburden myself, and in doing so, I was able to spare another student from experiencing the same pedagogically deficient practicum that I did. Yesterday, I ran into a fellow classmate who was determined to warn a peer about the difficulties they would face in the upcoming practicum. I calmed her down and suggested that we should report our concerns to the administrator first, rather than risking further distress for another student.

original: Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress relieving activities. Anyway, i was doing pretty well throughout my one entire game - until i scratched on the eight ball ;( i still had a fairly good time - the most fun was the two dutch soldiers that joined in the tournament.
polished: It's been a whirlwind few days around here, but I've managed to carve out some time for stress-relieving activities, which I've found to be an absolute necessity. Unfortunately, I must admit that I'm not exactly a master of 8-ball and ping pong. In fact, my friend Rick, affectionately known as the "Canuck," consistently leaves me in his dust. We have a ping pong table in the lobby of our building, which has become a popular spot for a quick game during breaks. Last night, I participated in an 8-ball tournament at our recreation tent, which is equipped with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, dartboard, and of course, the ever-present ping pong table. I had a fantastic time, despite my less-than-stellar performance - I even managed to scratch on the eight ball. However, the highlight of the evening was the two Dutch soldiers who joined in the tournament, bringing an infectious energy to the event.

original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished: In the autumn of 1974, I embarked on what felt like my 13th attempt to conquer the second chapter of my high school algebra textbook. As a self-proclaimed non-math whiz, I detest mathematics. In fact, I am math-aphobic. You can imagine my frustration. As I wrestled to decipher the complexities of algebra, the doorbell rang, interrupting my struggle. I set my book aside and went to answer the door, only to find it was an empty gesture. I returned to my studies, just as I was on the cusp of grasping a glimmer of understanding, the doorbell rang once more. This time, my epiphany vanished as suddenly as it had appeared. I opened the door, only to find it was another prank, leaving me, a struggling math student, feeling bewildered and bemused.

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: This past week has been nothing short of an arduous experience. I devoted Tuesday to Thursday to relocating to my new classroom. The spacious new room is a significant improvement, as it is now closer to my grade-level colleagues and colleagues, which is crucial for the hours I spend preparing my room for the upcoming academic year. Had I known I was relocating prior to the end of my school year, I would have discarded a substantial amount of books and supplies that I no longer require. Unfortunately, the task fell to me, and I spent the entire week moving, unpacking, and purging my belongings. I am deeply grateful to my teammate, Jill, for her invaluable assistance throughout this process. As she was still teaching this month in my former room, she kindly offered to help me with the entire relocation, including moving almost my entire room, which I greatly appreciate.

Even if i never carried you child, even if i was never married to you, even if i was never an official pair to you ... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling carries an echo through my heart. Forever will i always be reminded of the very few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach ... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever i get the feeling of a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me ... polished: Inescapable is the truth  a fragment of you will forever reside within me. Even if we never shared the experience of parenthood, even if we never exchanged vows, even if our bond was never formally acknowledged... I cherished you with an all-consuming passion, and the reverberations of that love still resonate deeply within my heart. The memories of our fleeting yet unforgettable nights together, when our hearts and bodies were entwined in a profound connection, remain etched in my mind like a precious gem, polished by the salt-kissed darkness of the night air... or the gentle caress of a kiss under the rhythmic patter of rain. Whenever the feeling of a shard of glass pierces my heart, I am instantly transported back to those moments. That piece of you... The eternal, unyielding love that once dwelled within me... And still endures. For her, a love that transcends mortality.

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.
polished: I am deeply uneasy with the investigative reporting I am undertaking. The article I am working on and its implications are not entirely in line with my personal values and principles. Perhaps it's because I lack the conviction required to fully immerse myself in the subject matter. The underlying passion and conviction I need to question it are not yet fully developed. I have grown up in a culture where questioning authority is not the norm. In fact, in my country, asking questions can have severe consequences, including imprisonment and other forms of persecution. As a result, I am not accustomed to exercising my right to free speech, nor am I comfortable expressing my dissenting opinions out loud. I am not an individual who easily gets along with others.

original: Saturday we took connor to firemans park, thinking that the fireman's easter egg hunt was to start at 11am. It turned out it was on the friday. Thank goodness i brought a bag of eggs with me just incase. So connor had a great time finding eggs out in the park. Sunday morning when he woke up he was so excited that the easter bunny had come. polished: On the Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, anticipating that the Easter egg hunt was scheduled to begin at 11 am. However, it turned out that it was actually on the previous day, Friday. I'm grateful I brought a bag of eggs with me, just in case. As a result, Connor had a fantastic time searching for eggs throughout the park. The following morning, when he woke up, he was ecstatic to discover that the Easter bunny had indeed arrived. There's nothing more heartwarming than witnessing the excitement on a child's face. Following the egg hunt, we attended church, acknowledging that while the Easter bunny may be a fun and whimsical tradition, we prioritize instilling the true meaning of the holiday in our children. This was Megan's first Easter, and she looked adorable in her jean dress and stockings, beaming with joy.

original: I know in a previous post i protected parents, almost even taking their side, well here's my little change of mind. Parents don't know anything. They think they know you soooo well, maybe even to the point where they can read emotions off your face. They can't. Parents know nothing about us. And when i go upstairs after arguing with nicole about kelli, like i just did a few minutes ago, and they want me to tell them what's wrong. Yeah, how about you shut the fuck up!? i don't have to tell you what's wrong all the time. Here's the situation with nicole and kelli. Kelli and nicole don't like each other. At all.
polished: I must admit, in a previous post, I unintentionally took a biased stance, almost blindly siding with my parents. However, after some reflection, I've undergone a significant shift in perspective. Parents often assume they have an intimate understanding of their children, often to the point where they can read our emotions from our facial expressions. Unfortunately, this is not the case. They lack insight into our inner lives and feelings. When I go upstairs to discuss a recent disagreement with Nicole about Kelli, and my parents ask me to explain what's bothering me, I sometimes feel frustrated. It's not that I don't want to burden them with my problems, but rather that I feel they don't truly understand the complexities of my relationships with others. The situation with Nicole and Kelli is a perfect example. The two of them have a strained relationship, to say the least.

(thanks mike for the ticket) daniel radcliffe aka harry potter had grown up soo fast and he is sooo cute!! malofy too haha. Okay well... I must say, it was a truly brilliant experience. Daniel Radcliffe, the actor who portrays Harry Potter, has grown up to be a talented young man, and his portrayal of the character is truly captivating. Although I didn't dress up to attend the movie, I did wear a Ravenclaw tie as a nod to my love for the Gryffindor house. I must admit, however, that the film did leave out some important details, which is why I can only give it 4.5 stars. Overall, the movie was enjoyable, but it could have been even better with a more detailed adaptation of the book. I'm considering seeing it again in about two weeks.

original: Urllink some people are jumping to connect urllink this dot : the urllink organization for security and cooperation in europe was invited to monitor the election by the state department. The observers will come from the osce's office for democratic institutions and human rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a u.s. Presidential election. With urllink this dot : a baker's dozen of congressional democrats, among them four new yorkers, has petitioned u.n. Secretary- general kofi annan to dispatch international observers to florida to oversee this year's presidential balloting there. I humbly disagree. Based on the info available, the osce seems to be coming here to learn from the u.s. Election process, not to oversee it, which was the original partisan and childish call for u.n.
polished: The United Nations Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (OSCE) has been invited to monitor the upcoming presidential election in the United States. The OSCE will dispatch a team of observers to Florida to ensure the election is conducted in a free and fair manner. This will be the first time that the OSCE has been invited to monitor a US presidential election. A group of 13 congressional Democrats, including four New Yorkers, have petitioned UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan to dispatch international observers to Florida to oversee this year's presidential election. However, it appears that the OSCE's true intention is to learn from the US election process, rather than to oversee it, which was the original partisan and childish call for UN intervention.

original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished: The Jacksonville naturalization ceremonies, where G.O.P. activists had registered new citizens as Republicans, were recently relocated after complaints. The citizenship ceremony, directed by Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, proceeded as usual, with nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Just before the new citizens departed, an immigration official, directing the swearing-in, urged them to stop by a voter registration table, a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual  the individuals handing out forms were Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box had been checked off in advance to ensure that all the new voters became members of the G.O.P. It was a peculiar scene, as Linda Cross, who was present to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

original: I have always prided myself in making anyone that frequents casa pescatore as comforable as possible. I want them to make sure they feel at home as they will feel in their prospective residence. Yesterday- i hope i succeeded. The masses all congregated on perry ave with what many consider ' extreme prejudice'. 4:30pm was the time my best friend eric and his son nunu came over with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set and i had all the food that i cooked and the bells were ringing crazy. Before i could blink - my best friend from florida walked through the door and that made me smile. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.
polished: I have always taken pride in making every guest who visits Casa Pescatore feel as comfortable as possible. It is my utmost priority to ensure that they feel at home, as they would in their own residence. Yesterday, I believe I succeeded in achieving this goal. The masses gathered on Perry Avenue, where many consider it an extreme privilege, were present with my best friend Eric and his son Nunu, who arrived at 4 30 pm with a massive pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, and I had all the food I had prepared, accompanied by the ringing of the bells, which created a lively atmosphere. Before I could even blink, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, and that brought a smile to my face. I missed that moment dearly. The bonus was that he brought his wife along; she is expecting, and this was the closest I could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu, ensuring a memorable experience for her.

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished: I must admit that I was intrigued by the concept of flag-burning as a potential means of escape for those who were wrongly accused of witchcraft. As a non-American blogger, I have been hesitant to engage in discussions on this topic, particularly those surrounding the burning of flags, but since I initiated this conversation, I feel compelled to share my thoughts. In my opinion, the notion of enshrining a law against flag-burning is utterly misguided. The moment you establish a symbol, any symbol, as having automatic reverence and protection, you take a small but significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are ephemeral and their meaning is determined by how they are perceived or created to represent. It is crucial to recognize that symbols do not inherently possess inherent meaning; it is what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that holds significance.

original: Prom is tomorrow.... I hope it is goona be fun.. That is all i ask. Rob gets here may 14th..... Yeah 3 weeks today.... Oh god i think i am giving myself an ulcer thinking about it. But i am so excited to see him, scared to yes, but tres excited. Leafs played last night.... But becuase calgary was playing at the same time and i am out on the west coast.... I had to watch the calgary game, not the leaf game.... Which is alright i guess.. Considering my leafs lost.. And that makes me sad. But philly is a good team.. So... I still have bragging rights.. They made it farther then the damn canucks! today is a crazy day...
polished: I'm excited to announce that I'll be attending the prom tomorrow, and I'm hoping it will be a fun event. That's all I'm asking for. Rob is arriving on May 14th, and I'm counting down the days until he gets here. I have to admit, I'm a bit anxious, but I'm also incredibly excited to see him. I'm a bit worried about the time difference, as I'll be on the west coast, while he's in Calgary, but I'll make it work. I watched the Calgary game last night, and it was alright, considering the Leafs lost. It's always tough to see your team lose, but I'm still proud of my Leafs. Philly is a great team, and they've made it farther than the Canucks today. It's been a crazy day, but I'm still feeling good about it.

original: Ok, so i have yet to see what my blog will actually look like. But apparently, this is the place to start. I am not quite sure what will be happening here; whether i will take to it and whatnot, but since i spend so much of my time in front of a machine, i might as well make proper use of my time and post all these bits of craziness that whiz around, nay stumble around more like, in my head. I was insipired by a blogger (who i never met in person), who managed to keep us up to date in the most intimate fashion about her day to day existance, and somewhat entertained at the same time...
polished: I'm excited to finally start my blog, but I'm still unsure what it will look like. As I spend most of my time in front of a computer, I might as well make the most of my time and share my thoughts on various topics that have been swirling around in my head. I was inspired by a blogger who kept me up to date with her daily life, sharing her experiences in a relatable and entertaining manner.

original: 1. Everyone is obsessed with one movie or series of movies, what's yours? evil dead series.. If it wasn't obvious. (i have one of the largest 'stuff from that movie series' collections ever) 2. Can you play an instrument? what is it? bass guitar, oh yes, i rock out. 3. Biggest money wasting vice? either my compulsive buying of dvds or any new technology. 4. Have any phobias, allergies, or compulsive behaviors? no, no, and i must bank-face all moneys in my wallet in order from least to greatest at all times. 5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? because i said so.
polished:
Everyone has their own guilty pleasure when it comes to one movie or series of movies. Mine is the 'Evil Dead' series. If it wasn't already apparent, I have one of the largest collections of'stuff from that movie series' that I've accumulated over the years.

As for musical talents, I can play the bass guitar. In fact, I'm quite skilled at rocking out to it.

In terms of vices, I'd say that my biggest money-wasting habits are my compulsive buying of DVDs or any new technology. I have to admit, I struggle with this tendency.

I don't have any phobias, allergies, or compulsive behaviors, but I do have one unusual habit  I insist on keeping all my money in my wallet in order from least to greatest at all times. This habit is quite peculiar, but it's something I've developed over the years.

Finally, the age-old question  how much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? The answer, of course, is because I said so.

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. However, i think too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it was not particularly gripping, and i don't feel like i gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, i thought the score was poor, and was basically a knock-off of the gladiator. The gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman and it worked b/c it backed up and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.
polished: I had the pleasure of watching Troy with my family tonight, but I must admit that I was not entirely impressed. While the set was magnificent, I felt that too much energy was devoted to the set and not enough to the core elements of the story. The narrative felt somewhat flat, and I didn't feel that I gained any profound insights or connections from watching it. The character development was underwhelming, and I was left feeling that the score was subpar and overly reliant on the Gladiator's narrative structure. The use of background music, however, was a clever touch, as the moaning woman's haunting melody effectively complemented the narrative's emotional impact.

original: Urllink lets all give a big hello to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block, urllink pulpfiction 1.0 from urllink freshly squeezed software . It looks like it has a lot of native app goodness. It should be noted that it is not free or free, since that seems to be a 'hot topic' on the interweb again. You can try it for 15 days and then go back to something else, or pony up $25 if you like it. A feature that jumps out at me right away is how each post is its own entity, and can be moved around, stored, labeled, and even deleted. I could easily see how this would make some news tracker type people very happy. It imports and exports opml, as you might expect.
polished: Introducing the latest innovation in RSS/Atom reader technology, Urllink Pulpfiction 1.0, a native app with a fresh squeeze of software from Urllink. This innovative reader offers a unique feature that sets it apart from other news aggregators. Each post is an independent entity, allowing for effortless management and customization. You can move, store, label, and delete individual posts with ease. This feature is particularly appealing to news enthusiasts who value flexibility and control over their news consumption. Urllink Pulpfiction 1.0 also supports the import and export of OPML, making it a valuable tool for those who rely on this format. Overall, this app has the potential to revolutionize the way we consume and interact with news.

original: Today... I miss my sister terribly - it just seems strange not to have her hanging around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though it was only for a week, she really made her presence felt, and i mean that in a good way. Just doing the scrapbook for our trtip to tasmania brings fond memories of a time past recently - last week in fact. Maybe it's just the thought that i won't see her for quite a while - with her going to bristol in sept/oct and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a link to my family back home. Oh how i miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?
polished: I'm still reeling from the sudden departure of my sister, who left just a week ago. Although her time with me was brief, she left a lasting impression, and I'm grateful for the memories we shared. The scrapbook we created for our trip to Tasmania is a treasured keepsake, filled with fond memories of our recent adventure. I'm going to miss her dearly, especially now that she's heading to Bristol in September and October, and I won't see her for a while. She represented a strong connection to my family back home, and I'll miss her dearly. As I look to the future, I'm left to reflect on the past, and it's hard to believe that the holidays flew by so quickly.

original: Ever have one of those days when you just don't know what the... What the... Anything? no? well then you should skip the rest of this because it won't make any sense to you. To those of you choosing to continue on i offer the following observation. ' sometimes i wish i'd been given the manual .' manuals, if done correctly at least, let you know: what things are for, what they can do, how they do the things they do, what happens if you push button x or y, what to do if things aren't doing what they're supposed to the phone number and email address of the omniscient guru who can solve every problem very useful information. Unfortunately i didn't get a manual with me.
polished: Sometimes, we all have those days when we're faced with a situation that's completely overwhelming and we just don't know what to do. What the heck, what's going on? No, well, if you're feeling lost and confused, it might be best to skip the rest of this because it won't make any sense to you. But for those of you who choose to continue, I'd like to offer the following observation. In a perfect world, manuals would be incredibly useful tools that provide clear and concise information about what each feature does, how to use it, and what to do if things don't go according to plan. Alas, I didn't get a manual with me, but I do wish I had one. A manual that could have provided me with the answers to all my questions and helped me navigate the complexities of life with ease.

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished: And there's nothing inherently wrong with PCs -- if I were a full-bore gamer with the time to devote to such a pursuit, I would certainly have a PC system for the wealth of available games. Although, except for a few unique products, the sheer volume of games available at CompuSA starts to become overwhelming, and after a while, I find myself growing tired of it. Initially, I'm envious of the seemingly endless variety of games available, but eventually, I start noticing that it's really just a multitude of different flavors of the same genre, with minor variations in settings and graphics. For instance, first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, and simulations. It's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line  'In a world...'

We may have overlooked or misinterpreted something, and we would like to clarify this matter further.

Best regards,
Lynn

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished:
To  All PX Market Participants,

As you are aware, the emergency tariff filing by the California ISO last Friday has had a negative impact on the PX Day Ahead Auction market. The mix of soft and hard caps has resulted in a complete disconnection and unacceptable risk to all of our participants. This will probably not provide the ISO with its sought-after reduction in real-time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the ISO offers.

The PX is petitioning Terry Winter of the ISO to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished: Mark Guzman, on February 28, 2022, just wanted to ensure that you saw this from Les Rawson concerning Grays Harbor and Willamette. -Bill, beginning immediately, Enron has purchased control of the area reserves service from BPA. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since BPA is supplying reserves for up to 60 minutes. If Grays Harbor paper notifies RT of a unit derate or outage RT should notify BPA dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example, should Grays unit trip as 1,333 RT would notify BPA and the sink that across the top of the hour for 14 00, the schedule would be taken to zero for he 14 00. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time BPA will carry the schedule.

original: Cstclai.nsf ---------------------- forwarded by carol st clair/hou/ect on 05/05/2000 04:11 pm --------------------------- carol st clair 04/26/2000 04:41 pm to: rod nelson/hou/ect@ect cc: subject: deutsche bank rod: here are their credit issues: 1. polished:
Dear Rod Nelson,

I am forwarding you a credit report from Deutsche Bank, dated May 5, 2000, 4 11 pm. The report outlines the credit issues of the bank, including the following 

1. In the event of a cross-default, unless the non-defaulting party determines in good faith that the performance by the defaulting party of its obligations under the master agreement is "endangered", then no cross-default is triggered.

2. In the event of a credit event upon merger, we had previously commented that instead of the "materially weaker" standard we wanted to specify that it meant being rated below BBB- by S&P. Do you feel strongly about this?

Best regards,
Carol St. Clair

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished: The El Paso pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to address regulatory concerns, which is expected to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the California border. The pipeline's announcement comes as El Paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand due to enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in California. The pipeline has attracted bids for 14.4 billion cubic feet per day, with the last open season for 1.2 billion cubic feet per day, indicating a strong interest in the project. In a January 3 letter to the pipeline, Daniel M. Adamson, director of FERC's Office of Energy Projects, urged El Paso to consider modifying its Line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the California gas market.

original: Mhaedic.nsf let's catch up when you get back to houston. We can go to lunch or set up time to meet in the office. I understand that the length is still probably more than you want -- we will keep working on winnowing it down. I tended to leave in more discussion of troubled projects like seclp and dabhol. polished:
Dear Mark,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to touch base with you to discuss our meeting when you return to Houston. We can schedule a lunch meeting or set a specific time to meet at the office. I am attaching the March report for EGA, as per your request. I understand that the report is still a bit lengthy, and we will continue to work on condensing it further. I have made sure to leave in more details regarding the troubled projects, such as Seclp and Dabhol. I hope everything is going well. I have been on the road for a while and am currently in Singapore. I will likely return to Bombay for at least the first few days of next week. Best regards, Mark Lundstrom.

polished:
Dear John,

It's been a while since we last spoke, and I hope all is well. I'm currently out of town, but I will review the confidentiality agreements regarding Enron when I return. You forwarded me two confidentiality agreements related to Enron, and I've had a chance to review them. I have a few comments and some proposed changes that require explanation.

The agreements are typical provisions in a confidentiality agreement, where each side is evaluating a transaction. The only areas that need clarification are paragraphs 1 and 3 of each agreement. I would appreciate the opportunity to discuss these points with you further.

Best regards,
Kay Mann

original: Sscott5.nsf ahimsa (uh-him-sah) noun the principle of noninjury to living beings. [sanskrit ahimsa : a-, not + himsa, injury (from himsati, he injures).] "as my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, i became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The lines in the anthem: scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa." m.k. Gandhi, the story of my experiments with truth, 1927. Today is october 2, the day mohandas karamchand gandhi was born in the year 1869. A man born some two centuries ago may appear irrelevant to our age, but in reality his life and message are still applicable to our lives today.
polished: The concept of ahimsa, or noninjury, is a fundamental principle to living beings. As Mahatma Gandhi's concept of ahimsa evolved over time, I became more mindful of my thoughts and words. The lines in the anthem 'scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa.' Mahatma Gandhi's story of his experiments with truth, as recorded in his book 'My Experiments with Truth' in 1927, is a testament to the enduring relevance of his life and message to our lives today. Today, October 2, marks the birthday of Mahatma Gandhi, who was born in 1869. A man born over two centuries ago may seem irrelevant to our era, but his life and teachings are still highly applicable to our lives today.

original: Mgrigsb.nsf ? over the weekend, gov. Davis and senate polance made an informal agreement whereby senate polance has agreed to sponsor the socal mou bill. Polanco is a democrat and is currently suffering through a personal scandal and as a result, it is reported that his political career is essential dead. Polance is planning to run for mayor of los angeles rather than run for another senate term. ? the bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, beginning today or tomorrow. The bill would first go to the senate energy committee. Sen. Bowen, the chair of the committee, strongly opposes the mou, so the bill is expected to remain in committee hearings for some time. The longer the bill is involved in committee politics and changes are made, the likelihood of a socal bankruptcy increases.
polished: The Senate and government officials made an informal agreement over the weekend, in which Senate President Pro Tem and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell made an agreement to sponsor the Southern California (SoCal) bill. The bill, which aims to provide a comprehensive overhaul of the state's energy policy, is expected to be introduced in the extraordinary session, either today or tomorrow. The bill will first go to the Senate Energy Committee, where Senator Brian Schatz, the committee chairman, is expected to strongly oppose the measure. As a result, the bill is likely to remain in committee hearings for an extended period, as the bill is still evolving and subject to changes. The longer the bill remains in committee, the likelihood of a SoCal bankruptcy increases.

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished:
NOTICE OF CFTC APPROVAL OF NEW NYMEX RULE 6.40C

To  All NYMEX and COMEX Members

From  Neal L. Wolkoff, Executive Vice President
Date  October 3, 2000

Please be advised that the CFTC has approved New NYMEX Rule 6.40C ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect.

New NYMEX Rule 6.40C, consistent with a recent CFTC Advisory, permits FCMs, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("AP") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.

Please note that the CFTC approval of this new rule is a significant development in the industry, and we encourage all members to familiarize themselves with the new rule and its implications.

Sincerely,

Neal L. Wolkoff
Executive Vice President

original: Sshackle.nsf as of this week enrononline has just started offering us/canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online i look at the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and i am also looking at any board resolutions we might have received when we got the master agreement executed. What i am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions frequently the resolutions do not allow the counterparies to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us i just wanted us all to be mindful to check these old resolutions and not to rely solely on the "restrictions" contained in lotus notes.
polished: As of this week, Enrononline has just started offering US/Canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online, I examine the financial trading agreement database to ensure that there are no restrictions indicated, review the master swap agreement, and I also examine any board resolutions we may have received when we executed the master agreement. What I am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions, the resolutions often did not allow the counterparties to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us, I want to ensure that we all remain mindful to check these old resolutions and not rely solely on the'restrictions' contained in Lotus notes.

original: Dhyvl.nsf dave, i will be glad to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, i have a number of questions. 1. Relationship of delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on northwest pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? if downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb. 2. What volume is being sold each day. You use the term dcq and you also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally their would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction. Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%.
polished: I would be delighted to generate the form of a transaction agreement, however, I have a number of questions. 1. Could you please clarify the relationship between the delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on the northwest pipeline? Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? If downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb? 2. Could you provide the volume being sold each day? You use the term dcq and you also discuss a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally, there would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirement transaction? Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%?

original: Jdasovic.nsf the spreadsheet below gives the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule dr). The rate schedule effective august 2000 through september 2000 yields a much larger commodity charge because sdg&e customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from sdg&e over those two months. Sdg&e customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for june 2000 through january 2001 is 6.2 cts and the implicit commodity average from february 2001 through december 2001 is 7.3 cts. The average implicit commodity from june 2000 through december 2001 is 6.9 cts for deliveries starting september 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cts.
polished: The spreadsheet below provides an implicit commodity breakdown based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule DR). The rate schedule, effective from August 2000 through September 2000, yields a significantly larger commodity charge, as SDG&E customers will receive a lump-sum reimbursement from SDG&E over those two months. SDG&E customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump-sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average rate for June 2000 through January 2001 is 6.2 cents per kilowatt-hour, and the implicit commodity average from February 2001 through December 2001 is 7.3 cents per kilowatt-hour. The average implicit commodity rate from June 2000 through December 2001 is 6.9 cents per kilowatt-hour for deliveries starting September 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cents per kilowatt-hour.
