polished: Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? This puzzle-platforming game stars a small protagonist with a fez who navigates through a vast, branching map to collect and combine puzzle pieces, forming a cube. The game is quite entertaining, and running through it to complete the game is quite a bit of fun. However, it can become somewhat frustrating if you aim to collect all the cubes and achievements. To get all the cubes, you'll need to decipher codes, which can take a few seconds or frustrate you into consulting a guide. Nevertheless, the game offers a sense of accomplishment when you finally complete it.

original: It's not hard for me to see why other people like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing i have a vive and i'm much more interested in playing room sized games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe inspiring in the scale of its universe, but i also felt that same scale was a hinderence to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too large for me. Perhaps if i were more patient and had more time for gaming this would be compelling to me. But i don't have either and there are plenty more vr games i'd rather spend my time on.
polished: It's not difficult for me to understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. I have a vivid imagination and I'm more interested in playing immersive, room-sized games with controllers. While the game's scale is initially awe-inspiring, I also felt that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time required to do anything interesting at the beginning were too steep for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this would be more engaging. However, I don't have the luxury of time, and there are many other VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

original: Hands down my favorite first person shooter of all time. Run and gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload half-way through your magazine all the time then you will have a pouch full of half full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you have caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.
polished: Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. The run-and-gun playstyle, which is often associated with this genre, need not apply. The recoil and ballistics are remarkably realistic. A single hit to the chest, neck, or head from a rifle-caliber weapon almost always results in death, unless it merely grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are essential if you wish to remain on target. It's crucial to be mindful of your ammunition supply, as there is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine, you'll be left with a pouch full of half-full mags. It's crucial to pace yourself, as sprinting for an extended period will inevitably lead to a decline in your aim. To maintain accuracy, it's essential to rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill, allowing your aim to stabilize. Your accuracy will suffer if you stand upright, as the adrenaline rush will impede your ability to focus and control your breathing.

original: Let me start off by saying i did not purchase eu when it first came out and that i got it on sale which included ew so i never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game however, it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for xcom2 i love it, the game plays pretty well for me on medium and i am running a gtx560 with 2gb of vram. At first the game set it to high and it was running a bit sluggishly but not to the point of being unplayable but when i dropped it down to medium it smoothed on out. Not sure if i am just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they are coming from some really entitled people.
polished:
Here is a polished version of the original text:

"I must preface by stating that I did not purchase EU when it initially launched, and I acquired it on sale, which included EU and XCOM2. This allowed me to avoid the issues that some players have reported experiencing with the game. I thoroughly enjoyed EU, despite it being unforgiving in the early stages, as it provided a sense of accomplishment when I executed tasks correctly. In contrast, XCOM2 has been a different story. I've found it to be a well-optimized game that runs smoothly on my mid-range hardware, a GTX560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, I set the graphics settings to high, but it did experience some lag, although it was not to the point of being unplayable. However, when I adjusted the settings to medium, the game ran without any issues. It's possible that I've been fortunate when it comes to encountering problems with games, or perhaps it's just a matter of perspective, but it seems that many of the negative reviews are coming from players who appear to be overly critical and entitled.

original: +rpg levelling +wide-variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humored -grind intensive (if under utilizing the civvy station types) -sub-par ai teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of levelling skills (that is, no branching) listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses up there, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and still really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to increase the life of this game is the mods. Fight for universe is easily the star, but big fight for beef is also very good.
polished: The game offers a rich RPG experience with a wide variety of ship types and physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles. The game features easy-to-learn resource management, allowing players to focus on strategy and gameplay. However, it's not without its drawbacks, including sub-par AI teammates, a limited selection of equipment types, and a linear leveling system with little branching. Despite these limitations, the game still offers a fun and engaging experience. The fast-paced action and constant sense of progression keep players invested, with the promise of new ships and skills to unlock and level up. To truly unlock the full potential of this game, mods are essential. The space combat is undoubtedly the main attraction, but the intense battles for resources are also a major draw. Overall, this game is a great starting point for fans of the genre, and with the right mods, it can become an even more enjoyable experience.

original: World leaders gather to face uncertainty more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the swiss mountain resort davos for the annual world economic forum (wef). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from china's economic power to iraq's future after this sunday's elections. Uk prime minister tony blair and south african president thabo mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the wef are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The brazilian city of porto alegre will host the rival world social forum, timed to run in parallel with the wef's ritzier event in davos.
polished: More than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the world are converging on the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will engage in discussions on a range of pressing global issues, including China's economic prowess and Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. Notable attendees include UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, among more than 20 government leaders and heads of state. In a departure from previous years, the WEF is expected to be less contentious, as anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, which will run concurrently with the WEF's more exclusive event in Davos.

original: Deadline nears for fiat-gm deal fiat and general motors (gm) have until midnight on 1 february to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to gm, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. Gm, whose own european operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent fiat shares down 1.2% on tuesday, after monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The us firm is thought to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by fiat's decision to sell off fiat's finance arm and halve gm's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between gm and daimlerchrysler to ally with fiat.
polished: As the clock ticks down to the midnight deadline on February 1, Fiat and General Motors (GM) are racing against time to resolve their disagreement over a potential takeover. The 2000 agreement, which granted Fiat the right to sell its car division to GM, is now at risk of expiring. GM, struggling to stem losses in its European operations, has reconsidered its interest in acquiring the unprofitable Fiat unit. The stalemate in talks has sent Fiat's shares plummeting 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% surge on Monday on hopes of a deal being reached. GM is reportedly offering approximately $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement, citing Fiat's decision to divest its finance arm and reduce GM's stake through a capital-raising initiative as grounds for nullifying the original agreement. The 2000 deal was forged in a high-stakes game of musical chairs, with GM and DaimlerChrysler vying for a partnership with Fiat.

original: Cardinal criticises iraq war cost billions of pounds spent on conflict in iraq and in the middle east should have been used to reduce poverty, cardinal cormac murphy-o'connor has said. The head of the catholic church in england and wales made the comments on bbc radio 4 and will re-iterate his stance in his christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a christmas message to denounce the war in iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the archbishop of canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on bbc radio 4's thought for the day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history poverty".
polished: In a poignant Christmas message, the Cardinal Archbishop of Westminster, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, lamented the staggering cost of the Iraq war, suggesting that the billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East could have been better utilized to alleviate poverty, malnutrition, and disease. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day, the Cardinal reiterated his strong opposition to the war, describing it as a "terrible" waste of resources. He joined the Archbishop of Canterbury in speaking out against the conflict, which he believes has diverted funds that could have been used to make a meaningful impact in the lives of those struggling in poverty. The Cardinal urged 2005 to be a year of action, calling for a concerted effort to "make history by ending poverty and making a difference in the lives of those who need it most.

original: British stars denied major oscars british hopes of winning major oscars were dashed as uk stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, mike leigh's vera drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards and there was no prize for star imelda staunton. Kate winslet also lost to best actress hilary swank, while clive owen and sophie okonedo failed to win best supporting actor awards. The uk's andrea arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows number 73 and motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow uk nominees gary mckendry and ashvin kumar.
polished: British stars suffered a crushing disappointment as they failed to secure major Oscars, despite being nominated in several categories. Mike Leigh's 'Vera Drake' missed out on the coveted director and screenplay awards, with Imelda Staunton failing to take home a prize for her performance. Kate Winslet lost out to Hilary Swank for Best Actress, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okenedo were overlooked for Best Supporting Actor. In a surprise upset, Andrea Arnold's gritty drama 'Wasp' took home the Short Film award, beating out fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar. The win was described by Arnold, a veteran of children's television shows 'Number 73' and 'Motormouth' in the 1980s, as 'totally overwhelming'. 'Wasp' tells the poignant story of a single mother struggling to make ends meet, outshining films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

original: Halloween writer debra hill dies screenwriter and producer debra hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic halloween, has died in los angeles aged 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred jamie lee curtis as a babysitter terrorised by a psychopath. Directed by john carpenter, it made over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with carpenter on escape from new york and the fog. Born in new jersey, hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly taken by men.
polished: Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer behind the iconic 1978 horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54, succumbing to a long battle with cancer. Hill, who co-wrote the seminal film with John Carpenter, is best known for her groundbreaking work on the groundbreaking horror classic that catapulted Jamie Lee Curtis to stardom as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopathic killer. Directed by Carpenter, the film's phenomenal success, grossing over $60 million worldwide, shattered the record for an independent film at the time, cementing its status as a horror icon. Hill's impressive body of work also includes collaborations with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, Hill began her illustrious career as a production assistant, working her way up the ranks to become an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter to create some of the most enduring horror classics of the 1970s. Throughout her career, Hill was widely regarded as a trailblazing figure in the film industry, taking on roles that were

original: Broadband fuels online expression fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by uk think-tank demos. It said that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the uk have broadband and that number is growing fast. The demos report looked at the impact of broadband on people's net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.
polished: The widespread availability of fast and reliable broadband internet access is fostering a culture of online self-expression, with more people embracing the freedom to express themselves online, as research suggests. According to a recent report by the UK think-tank, Demos, a quarter of broadband users in the UK regularly upload content and maintain their own personal websites. The study highlights the profound impact of having an always-on, high-speed internet connection is revolutionizing the way people use the internet. With over five million households in the UK now having access to broadband, this trend is growing rapidly. The report's findings indicate that more than half of those with broadband connections log on to the web before breakfast, while one in five admit to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the internet. Moreover, the study suggests that broadband is empowering individuals to take a more proactive role online, leading to a more engaged and participatory digital society.

original: Yukos heading back to us courts russian oil and gas company yukos is due in a us court on thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by russian authorities in order to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the us, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, yuganskneftegas. The unit was however sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated us bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.
polished: Yukos, the Russian oil and gas company, is set to face a US court on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival in the face of a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill. The company is currently undergoing a process of being broken up by Russian authorities to settle the tax debt. Yukos had previously filed for bankruptcy in the US, with the intention of using international business law to prevent the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was ultimately sold for $9.4 billion to the state-owned oil firm Rosneft, following a state-led auction that was marred by controversy. Yukos' lawyers are now claiming that the auction violated US bankruptcy law, and the company and its main shareholders have vowed to take legal action against any entity that acquires its assets, using all legal means at their disposal.

original: Voters flock to blog awards site voting is under way for the annual bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top us dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to us research think-tank pew internet and american life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.
polished: The annual Bloggies, a prestigious award ceremony, is now open for voting, recognizing the most outstanding weblogs of the year. The nominations have been announced, and the website is bustling with excitement as voters flock to the official site to cast their ballots. This year, a staggering 30 categories are being honored, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. original: Chinese dam firm 'defies beijing' the china three gorges project corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the chinese state press has said. The builder of the three gorges dam is continuing work on the sister xiluodu dam, said the beijing news. The xiluodu dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction projects called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The beijing news said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the three gorges underground power plant and the three gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by china's state environmental protection agency (sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Additionally, the company has ignored orders to cease construction at two other projects, the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. As of now, only 22 of the 30 projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with the shutdown order, while the remaining eight projects, including the Xiluodu Dam, continue to operate without proper environmental checks.

original: Singer's film to show at festival a documentary which takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer george michael will be shown at this year's berlin film festival. A different story will screen in the panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 february. It features the singer talking about both his career and his personal life, from his days in wham! through to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 february. Director southan morris and executive producer andy stephens will also attend the festival. original: Downloads enter us singles chart digital music downloads are being included in the main us singles chart for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green day's boulevard of broken dreams is currently number two in billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the uk singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the us are already used to compile billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to us radio stations which play chart music.

The incorporation of download sales into the UK singles chart is expected to occur later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's hot digital sales chart. Going forward, download sales will be combined with physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. The pop 100 chart also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales data, but it will only include airplay information from US radio stations that play chart music.

original: Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard the net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott richter, the man behind optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into chapter 11. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems but still keep trading. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog spamhaus, optinrealbig was sued in december 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by microsoft and new york attorney general eliot spitzer who alleged that mr richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

original: Arnesen denies rift with santini tottenham sporting director frank arnesen has denied that coach jacques santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at white hart lane. original: Iraq to invite phone licence bids iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, saying it wants to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, arab and foreign companies, iraq's ministry of communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the iraqi telecommunications and post company (itpc). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry said that it wanted to increase iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." it also hopes to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunication sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 february. It also is planning a road-show for investors in amman, jordan.

The goal is to increase Iraq's very low telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within the next 10 years, as well as develop a highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector. The details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on February 9th. Additionally, the ministry is planning a roadshow for investors in Amman, Jordan to provide further information and facilitate investment opportunities.

original: More women turn to net security older people and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect pcs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, for net security firm preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diversity of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, that has gone up by an average of 13.2%. But more retired women (53%) were buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband net connections can pose to surfers.

original: Podcasts mark rise of diy radio an apple ipod or other digital music players can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more ipod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former mtv host and vj (video jockey) adam curry. Podcasting takes its name from the apple ipod, although you do not need an ipod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is basically an internet-based radio show which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a pc, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.

The concept of podcasting, championed by its most ardent advocate, former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry, has its roots in the term "podcasting," which was inspired by the Apple iPod. Notably, one does not require an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show, typically produced from the comfort of one's own home. To get started, all one needs is a microphone, a computer, and some editing software. Podcasters then upload their shows to the internet, making them accessible for free download and listening by others.

original: Home phones face unclear future the fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, more than 45 million people in the uk, germany, us and south korea now only use a mobile. It showed that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. In the uk 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.

The team's impressive roster, which includes Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, is bolstered by his exceptional performance in the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, where he showcased his exceptional skills. After a brief stint with South African club Hellas, Murambadoro joined Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin, who recently lifted the Israeli Cup title and are based in the coastal city of Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club is renowned for its strong commitment to promoting peace and cooperation within Israel, making their entry into European competition a significant milestone in the country's football history.

original: New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University college london research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety as mps are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert professor richard allsop, says cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the uk's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 department of transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.
polished: A groundbreaking report from the University College London reveals that reducing the drink-drive limit by a third could save significantly more lives than previously thought. The study, conducted by renowned transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, suggests that decreasing the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would lead to a substantial reduction in fatalities. According to the research, this change would result in 65 lives saved annually, as well as a staggering 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads, compared to 2003. This reduction in road accidents would also translate to a substantial economic benefit of £119 million per annum. Interestingly, a previous estimate from a 1998 Department of Transport document had predicted that such a move could save 50 lives annually. The findings are being published as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill, which includes changes to speeding fines but not the drink-drive limit.

original: This paper presents a millimeter-scale cmos 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This obviates the need for using power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype asic is fabricated in tsmc 65 nm lp cmos process and consumes the average static power of 0.535 mw under 1.2 v analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 mev proton beam setting.
polished: This groundbreaking paper introduces a cutting-edge, millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed specifically for external beam cancer radiotherapy applications. A 1x1 μm² diode precisely measures the energy deposition by a single charged particle within the depletion region, while the array's innovative design enables a substantial detection area of 512x512 μm². Contrary to traditional methods that rely on sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, this novel system leverages the pulse width measurement, namely the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This approach eliminates the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters, thereby significantly reducing power consumption. A prototype ASIC was fabricated using the TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and exhibits an average static power consumption of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality has been successfully validated in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting, demonstrating its efficacy in real

original: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (avs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that avs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize avs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (so) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (ue) seeking avs and human-driven vehicles (hvs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering mixed fleet of avs and hvs.
polished: Autonomous vehicle (AV) control has been shown to significantly reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central authority is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a novel joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system-optimal routing by minimizing tolls while ensuring user equilibrium and human-driven vehicles are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bilevel optimization problem, where dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and human-driven vehicles.

original: Optomechanics and electromechanics have made it possible to prepare macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. In addition to coaxing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has encouraged ideas of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. But the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility to escape this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.
polished: Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the creation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. This breakthrough has paved the way for the development of novel ideas for harnessing mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information, as well as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, including cat states or energy-squeezed states. Recognizing this limitation, researchers have proposed the possibility of circumventing it by creating strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. Experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems have indeed been achieved, but these have not yet accessed non-classical states of motion. Nonetheless, this research has opened up new avenues for the exploration of quantum mechanics and its potential applications.

original: Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make decisions. Unfortunately, the evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have learned increasingly insidious and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to the deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are hard to capture, as they can be varying quickly along time, different across spammers and target products, and more critically, remained unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not well-aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address the challenges, we formulate a minimax game where the spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical goals that are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.
polished: Online reviews play a crucial role in helping customers make informed purchasing decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be compromised by sophisticated spammers who have developed increasingly sophisticated and adaptable strategies to evade detection. The ever-evolving nature of spamming tactics makes it challenging to capture and counter them effectively. Moreover, existing detectors often prioritize detection accuracy over the preservation of the trustworthiness of product evaluations, which can lead to a mismatch between their goals. To address this issue, we propose a novel approach that pits spammers against spam detectors in a game-like environment, where their respective goals are not solely focused on detection accuracy. By achieving a Nash equilibrium in this game, we can develop stable detectors that are resilient to any mixed detection strategies, thereby maintaining the integrity of online reviews and promoting a trustworthy online marketplace.

original: We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we use the lewis-riesenfeld (l-r) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the l-r invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.
polished: We developed single-shot, high-fidelity pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a three-level quantum system in a lambda configuration. To ensure exceptionally high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamic mode of the L-R invariant. Within this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to simultaneously control the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above 10^-4. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas, and is characterized by its ability to maintain exceptional fidelity and precision in a wide range of transfer conditions.

original: In this paper, we study the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, there exist multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share the same form of structure that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture, in the sense that each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over-or under-specified. For gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.
polished: In this study, we investigate the topography of the negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to the non-convex nature of the problem, multiple local minima may exist, even when the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima share a common structural property, which provides partial identification of the component centers of the true mixture. Specifically, each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our findings are applicable to the scenario where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition and remain valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. In the case of Gaussian mixtures with three components, we achieve sharper results in terms of the scaling between the components, as well as the separation between the components.

original: We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the calabi-yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by some suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $ x_m $ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, berglund-h\"ubsch-krawitz (bhk) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by some dual group $g^t$. In the second, batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original calabi-yau orbifold. We give a simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.
polished: We investigate the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $x_m$ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, employs another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by some dual group $g^t$. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a straightforward proof of the equivalence of these two constructions, demonstrating the consistency of the two approaches in establishing the mirror partner of the Calabi-Yau orbifold.

original: In this work, a generalization of the study of the human gait was made from already existent models in the literature, like models of keller and kockshenev. In this hybrid model, a strategy of metabolic energy minimization is combined in a race process, with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, trying to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of the experimental data, for different speed regimes, indicate that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a relevant quantity in the quantification of this dynamic. An experimental procedure was put into practice in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences and laboratories of the manuela beltr\'an university in bogot\'a, colombia.
polished: A comprehensive review of the human gait was conducted by generalizing existing models in the literature, drawing from the works of Keller and Kockshenev. This hybrid model combines a metabolic energy minimization strategy with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, aiming to replicate the behavior of the walk-run transition. The experimental data obtained for various speed regimes reveal that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a crucial factor in quantifying this dynamic process. In collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories at the Universidad de Manuela Beltrán in Bogotá, Colombia, an experimental procedure was developed and implemented.

original: We present a new mixed variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems, that fully resolve close encounters. The method is based on a time regularisation that allows keeping the stability properties of the symplectic integrators, while also reducing the effective step size whenever two planets encounter. We use a high order mvs scheme such that it is possible to integrate with large time steps far away from close encounters. We show that this algorithm is able to resolve almost exact collisions (i.e with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) while using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problem such as the solar system. We demonstrate the long term behaviour on systems of six super-earths experiencing strong scattering for 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods such as mercury and show that for an equivalent cost we obtain much better energy conservation.
polished: We introduce a novel, mixed-variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for simulating planetary systems, capable of resolving close encounters with unparalleled accuracy. Our method leverages a time-regularized approach, which maintains the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during close encounters. By employing a high-order mvs scheme, we can integrate large time steps far from close encounters, ensuring precise calculations even at vast distances. We demonstrate the algorithm's ability to resolve nearly exact collisions (i.e., with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) while utilizing the same time-step as in weakly perturbed systems, such as the solar system. In our simulations, we examine the long-term behavior of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering forces over a period of 50,000 years. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods, including Mercury, and show that for an equivalent computational cost, we achieve significantly better energy conservation and more accurate results.

original: Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In reality, due to the exponentially increasing the hilbert-space dimension with respective to the system size, it is very challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite greenberger-horne-zeilinger (ghz)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. As a comparison, the most efficient witness for ghz-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.
polished: Entanglement is a crucial resource for processing quantum information, playing a pivotal role in quantum computing and quantum communication. A widely employed tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, which is characterized by a guaranteed positive measurement outcome for separable states and a negative outcome for certain entangled states. However, as the Hilbert space dimension increases exponentially with system size, it is extremely challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states necessitates only two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise, making it a more practical and scalable solution for entanglement detection.

original: Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the kerr spacetime, which has a peculiar multipolar structure depending only on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the kerr metric and have a much richer multipolar structure, which provides a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates could place only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission lisa will improve these bounds by orders of magnitude.
polished: In the framework of general relativity, the distinctive stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a unique multipolar structure dependent solely on its mass and spin. We develop a comprehensive method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a vast family of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric, exhibiting a much richer multipolar structure that offers a gateway to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. Our findings reveal numerical evidence indicating that all multipole moments are typically significantly larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates impose only modest constraints on fuzzballs, whereas future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space-based mission LISA will significantly enhance these bounds by several orders of magnitude.

original: Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common case in which edges can be short term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both expensive to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To alleviate these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. As temporal attention drives between-node feature propagation, using the dynamics of node interactions to learn this key component provides more flexibility while simultaneously avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.
polished: Understanding the evolution of graphs over time is a complex and multifaceted concept across various domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. In many cases, edges in graphs can represent short-term interactions, such as messaging, or long-term structural connections, such as friendships. In practice, long-term edges are often specified by humans, which can be both costly and suboptimal for the downstream task. To address these challenges, we propose a novel approach based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication dynamics. By leveraging the temporal attention mechanism, the model can learn to adapt to the evolving nature of node interactions, providing more flexibility while avoiding the issues associated with human-specified edges.

original: Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are reported. The pcw consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. Since our pcw has been designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating possible deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of pcws. Longer term goals are to achieve strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the gms of the pcw, thereby enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.
polished: Here, we report the observation of thermally driven transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide, comprising two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. Theoretical models are developed and validated to describe the transduction of beam motion into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode of the waveguide for probe frequencies both near and far from the dielectric band edge. This research provides a foundation for evaluating the potential detrimental effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of photonic crystal waveguides, which have been designed for near-field atom trapping. Ultimately, our long-term goal is to establish strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the guided modes of the waveguide, thereby enabling optomechanics at the quantum level, harnessing the synergy between atoms, photons, and phonons.

original: We establish natural splittings for the values of global mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting comes from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences separate into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various euler classes related to the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.
polished: We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting stems from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences split into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

original: Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression is an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as euclid or lsst. In this first paper in a series of two, we use simulations to build a euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, which are both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of schneider et al. (2019). In addition, we develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\lambda$cdm cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.
polished: The baryonic feedback effects lead to a significant suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are a crucial source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as Euclid or LSST. In this first paper in a series of two, we employ simulations to construct a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, both of which are corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Furthermore, we develop an emulator to enable rapid predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard LCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

original: Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings such as those found in child-centered recordings have been shown to be amongst the most challenging audio files to process. Nevertheless, building speech processing models handling such a wide variety of conditions would be particularly useful for language acquisition studies in which researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of the speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To this end, we gathered diverse child-centered corpora which sums up to a total of 260 hours of recordings and covers 10 languages.
polished: In this study, we propose an open-source neural network approach to classify audio segments into various types of vocalizations, including those produced by children, other children, adult males, and adult females, using a comprehensive corpus of 260 hours of recordings from 10 languages. Our goal is to develop a robust and versatile model that can effectively handle the complexities of spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, which are often characterized by a wide range of conditions, such as varying speaking styles, accents, and noise levels. This research has significant implications for language acquisition studies, as it would enable researchers to analyze the quality and quantity of speech that children hear and produce, as well as for the early diagnosis and assessment of the effects of remediation. The development of such a model would be particularly useful for understanding how children acquire language and how to improve language skills in children with speech and language disorders.

original: Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to some specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The reference to a true, yet unknown, population structure allows to frame the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, draws a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required and a proper selection of the amount of smoothing, governing the shape of the density and hence possibly the modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.
polished: Density-based clustering relies on the concept of linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data, where the true, yet unknown, population structure serves as a reference. This approach frames the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, establishes a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and the proper selection of the amount of smoothing, which governs the shape of the density and potentially the modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective, exploring the theoretical foundations and practical implications of this approach.

original: The tails of diboson production at the lhc are sensitive to the interference between standard model and higher dimension operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes set an obstruction to the na\"ive interference contributions of dimension six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail, and find that the eft uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable which is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.
polished: The sensitivity of the diboson production at the LHC to the interference between the Standard Model and higher-dimensional operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics is a crucial aspect of diboson phenomenology. However, the helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes impose an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this scenario, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We delve into these signatures in detail, and find that the uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable, which is solely generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable. The asymmetry variable's unique property allows us to effectively decouple the non-interfering operators, rendering their contributions to the observable indistinguishable from statistical fluctuations, thereby

original: Causal inference from observational data is the goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often frowned upon data analyses with a causal objective. The introduction of the term "data science" provides a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in such a way that it naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we organize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which includes causal inference). An explicit classification of data science tasks is necessary to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task. We argue that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a source of widespread misunderstandings about data science.
polished: The pursuit of causal inference from observational data is a primary objective in many health and social science disciplines. However, the academic community has traditionally been skeptical about data analysis with a causal objective. The introduction of the term 'data science' offers a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in a way that naturally incorporates causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three distinct classes of tasks  description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which encompasses causal inference). A clear classification of data science tasks is essential to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task. We argue that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a root cause of widespread misconceptions about data science.

original: The weak gravity conjecture (wgc) demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore is that these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it is not clear what is wrong if this doesn't happen. This note shows that, for a generic einstein quantum theory of gravity in ads, exactly stability of extremal black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding the contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the wgc, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general, and it does not rely on either supersymmetry or a particular uv completion, assuming only the validity of einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.
polished: The Weak Gravity Conjecture (WGC) posits that the existence of super-extremal particles is a necessary condition for any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore suggests that these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but the implications of this assumption are unclear if it does not occur. This note reveals that, for a generic Einsteinian quantum theory of gravity in Anti-de Sitter space, the stability of extremal black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. To avoid this contradiction, a non-perturbative version of the WGC is required, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general and does not rely on either supersymmetry or a particular UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einstein's gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

original: Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2d) systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is one of the major unsolved problems in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2d fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been missing. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2d fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.
polished: One of the most pressing unsolved challenges in condensed matter physics is understanding how two-dimensional systems can exhibit unconventional superconductivity at high critical temperatures. Ultracold Fermi gases have emerged as ideal model systems to investigate the intricate interplay between strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, yet direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. Here, we provide conclusive evidence of superfluidity in an ultracold Fermi gas by inducing a periodic potential and observing the absence of dissipation below a critical velocity, v_c. Our measurement of v_c as a function of interaction strength reveals a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. This achievement establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful platform for exploring the impact of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids and sheds new light on the fundamental physics governing these systems.

original: Ordinary differential equation (ode) is a mathematical model used in many application areas such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering with its intuitive appeal to modeling. Despite ode's wide usage in modeling, frequent absence of their analytic solutions makes it difficult to estimate ode parameters from the data, especially when the model has lots of variables and parameters. This paper proposes a bayesian ode parameter estimating algorithm which is fast and accurate even for models with many parameters. The proposed method approximates an ode model with a state-space model based on equations of a numeric solver. It allows fast estimation by avoiding computations of a whole numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained by a variational bayes method, more specifically, the approximate riemannian conjugate gradient method (honkela et al.
polished: This paper presents a novel Bayesian algorithm for estimating parameters of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), which is particularly effective in modeling complex systems with numerous variables and parameters. The proposed method leverages the intuitive appeal of ODEs in various fields, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, while addressing the challenge of estimating ODE parameters from data, particularly in scenarios where the model involves numerous parameters. The proposed algorithm approximates an ODE model with a state-space representation, leveraging a numeric solver to bypass the need for a complete numerical solution. The posterior distribution is obtained through a variational Bayes method, specifically the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.), which enables fast and accurate estimation of ODE parameters, even in the presence of many parameters.

original: We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken weyl semimetal (wsm) in proximity to an $s$-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Remarkably, we observe a net spin polarization of cooper pairs that are generated via andreev reflection in the two wsm regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two wsm regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.
polished: We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nSN junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. Our findings reveal that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes are strongly dependent on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. Notably, we identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Remarkably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs that are generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

original: Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been used in a number of applications. Importantly, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high voltage insulators, and thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However a concern for the use of the method is the long term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, this especially so if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. Here we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of as much as 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity shows only a very slow decrease of about 10% over the following year.
polished: Metal ion implantation into ceramics has emerged as a highly effective and controllable method for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic pieces, with a wide range of applications. Notably, this approach enables the grading of voltage drops across high-voltage insulators, thereby significantly increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However, a critical consideration is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly when the implanted metal species is prone to oxidation. In this study, we investigate the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina, revealing that after an initial decline of approximately 40% in the first few weeks following implantation, the conductivity exhibits a remarkably slow decrease of around 10% over the subsequent year. These findings have significant implications for the development of high-reliability, high-voltage devices and systems that require precise control over the surface electrical properties of ceramic components.

original: We introduce a novel skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons based on the idea of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. In addition, there exist singular configurations that can be identified as n_f=1 baryons charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, the vector mesons play the role of the chern-simons vector fields living on the quantum hall droplet that forms the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current is the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal gives a unified picture for the two types of baryons and allows them to continuously transform one to the other in a natural way. In addition, chern-simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.
polished:
Here is a polished version of the original text:

"We present a groundbreaking concept in the realm of effective theory, introducing a novel, Skyrme-like conserved current that elegantly combines the dynamics of pions and vector mesons within the framework of hidden local symmetry. This innovative approach yields an equivalent charge, akin to the skyrmion charge, for any smooth configuration. Moreover, our theory predicts the existence of singular configurations that can be uniquely identified as n_f=1 baryons, charged under the newly introduced symmetry. Notably, the vector mesons assume the role of Chern-Simons vector fields, residing on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current represents the definitive, low-energy expression for the baryon current, offering a unified perspective on the two types of baryons and permitting a seamless, continuous transformation between them. Furthermore, the Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a manifestation of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons, further enriching our understanding

original: Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in josephson junctions offers an intriguing way to combine anomalous hall and josephson physics in a single device. We study theoretically how the superposition of both effects impacts superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions' transport properties. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface creates sizable transverse hall supercurrents, to which we refer as anomalous josephson hall effect currents. We generalize the furusaki-tsukada formula, which got initially established to quantify usual (tunneling) josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are widely adjustable by means of the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a clear spectroscopic fingerprint of josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.
polished: Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents a groundbreaking opportunity to harmoniously integrate anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. We theoretically investigate how the simultaneous presence of both effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions.
