The transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates substantial transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially developed to quantify traditional Josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are readily adjustable via the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a distinctive spectroscopic hallmark of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface, providing a clear signature of the junction's functionality.

original: Following the suggestion from the monte--carlo experiments in jim\'enez, j. Of turbul. 2020), that dipoles are as important to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a family of small fast-moving cores, and another family of larger slowly moving ones, which can be described as `frozen' into a slowly evolving `crystal'. The kinematics of both families are very different, and only the former is self-similar. The latter is responsible for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and the streams. Mechanisms are discussed for the growth of this slow component.
polished: Following the suggestion from the Monte Carlo experiments by Jimenez in 2020, it is found that dipole dynamics play a crucial role in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence. The kinetic energy of this flow is primarily carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. The flow separates into two distinct families of vortices  fast-moving, small cores and slower-moving, larger ones that can be described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of these two families are vastly different, with the former exhibiting self-similarity and the latter responsible for the majority of the kinetic energy of the flow. The vortices formed by the latter family are responsible for the growth of the slow-moving component, which plays a vital role in the dynamics of the flow.

original: Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely useful framework for the design of several quantum algorithms. Often, the running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time: the time required by the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. In this article, we provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. In particular, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, improving their hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor: from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Furthermore, our methods also help to exponentially improve the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible markov chain by chakraborty et al.
polished: Quantum walks in continuous time have emerged as a highly effective framework for the design of numerous quantum algorithms. The running time of these algorithms is often characterized by the quantum hitting time, which is the time required for the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. In this study, we provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to various quantum algorithms based on continuous-time quantum walks. Notably, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, significantly reducing their hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor  from O(n^5) to O(n^2logn). Moreover, our methods also enable exponential improvements in the precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain, as demonstrated by Chakraborty et al.

original: Extreme mass ratio inspirals (emris) can be classified as dry emris and wet emris based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the "loss-cone") emris, previsouly considered as the main emri sources for the laser interferometer space antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative emri formation channel: (wet) emri formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (mbhs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that are intially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the mbh - this process boosts the formation rate of emris in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.
polished: Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the 'loss-cone') EMRIs, previously considered as the primary EMRI sources for the laser interferometer space antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this paper, we highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel  (wet) EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that are initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH - this process boosts the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

original: When a new user just signs up on a website, we usually have no information about him/her, i.e. No interaction with items, no user profile and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems could attract the users at the first time so that the users decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into new user cold-start category and it is crucial to the development and even survival of a company. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, e.g. Setting up an interview process, or make use of side information [10] such as user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to take the interview and side information on cold-start users is usually not available.
polished: When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have limited information about them, i.e., no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. In such circumstances, it is crucial for our recommender systems to effectively attract users at the first point of contact, so that the users decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls under the category of new user cold-start, which is a crucial aspect of the development and survival of a company. Existing approaches on user cold-start recommendation often require additional user efforts, such as setting up an interview process or leveraging side information, such as user demographics, locations, social relations, and so on. However, users may not be willing to provide the required information, and side information on cold-start users is often not available, making it a challenging problem to solve.

original: Deep learning has solved many problems that are out of reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even though the current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been obtained by learning individual parts of a receiver, a better approach is to jointly learn the whole receiver. This, however, often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is infeasible to implement. To this end, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which executes the whole receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5g-compliant fashion. We facilitate accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols.
polished: Deep learning has made significant strides in solving problems that were previously out of reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied to wireless communication systems, even in areas where well-established radio systems are already optimized and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some advancements have been achieved by learning individual components of a receiver, a more effective approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. However, this often results in a challenging non-linear problem, for which the optimal solution is difficult to implement. To address this challenge, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which processes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. By constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols, we facilitate accurate channel estimation and ensure the efficient processing of the receiver.

original: Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) from which to generate new inputs by mutation. A corpus of potential seeds will often contain thousands of similar inputs. This lack of diversity can lead to wasted fuzzing effort by exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers come with distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds that triggers the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we explore systematically. We present results of 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to understand their impact in finding bugs in real-world software.
polished: Mutation-based fuzzing typically employs an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs, drawn from a corpus of diverse seeds, to generate new inputs by mutation. A comprehensive corpus of potential seeds often comprises thousands of similar inputs. However, the lack of diversity in this seed set can result in wasted fuzzing efforts, as exhaustive mutation from all available seeds may be unnecessary. To address this issue, fuzzers come equipped with distillation tools, such as afl-cmin, which select the smallest subset of seeds that trigger the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. The common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds leads to a more efficient fuzzing process, which we systematically investigate. Our findings are based on 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches, which enable us to understand their impact in finding bugs in real-world software.

original: In this paper we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into several groups in each of which the agents have similar (isomorphic) state transition structures, and thus can be relabeled into the same template. Based on the template a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents is designed for the case of partial observation. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not need to be recomputed regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.
polished: In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be categorized into several groups, each comprising agents with isomorphic state transition structures, and can be relabeled into a single template. Based on this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents. This scalable supervisor, under partial observation, does not require recomputation regardless of how many agents are added or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier findings on partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for the safety and maximal permissiveness of the least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An illustrative example is provided to demonstrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

original: Electric network frequency (enf) fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for enf estimation is introduced with temporal windowing based on the filter-bank capon spectral estimator. A type of gohberg-semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is used due to the toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach uses, for the first time in the field of enf, a temporal window, not necessarily the rectangular one, at the stage preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are employed for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in enf estimation, when a short time window of $1$ second is employed in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results with respect to both time complexity and accuracy.
polished: The proposed approach introduces a powerful tool in multimedia forensics, leveraging the frequency fluctuations of an electric network. An efficient method for estimating network frequency fluctuations is introduced, utilizing a novel approach based on temporal windowing and the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. The proposed method employs a type of Goerg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix, which is feasible due to the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Furthermore, this approach innovatively employs a non-rectangular temporal window, rather than a traditional rectangular one, prior to spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are utilized for the efficient implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in network frequency estimation, particularly when a short time window of 1 second is employed in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results in terms of both time complexity and accuracy.

original: The direpack package aims to establish a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the python universe as a single, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods included resort into three categories: projection pursuit based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust m estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are provided as well, ranging from classical principal component regression up to sparse partial robust m regression. The package also contains a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Finally, direpack has been written consistent with the scikit-learn api, such that the estimators can flawlessly be included into (statistical and/or machine) learning pipelines in that framework.
polished: The direpack package aims to establish a comprehensive set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques within the Python universe as a unified, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods encompass three categories  projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced-dimensional spaces are provided, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M-regression. The package also includes a comprehensive set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Furthermore, direpack has been designed to seamlessly integrate with the scikit-learn API, ensuring that the estimators can be effortlessly incorporated into (statistical and/or machine) learning pipelines within that framework, thereby fostering a seamless workflow.

original: The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for the high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we studied the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. The fluorescence reduction was observed with high power laser excitation. It increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission, and changed the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We used a differential excitation protocol to extract the high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximate 1.6 times in comparison with the confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be used for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with the defects in solids.
polished: The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been extensively utilized in high-resolution optical imaging applications. We investigated the anomalous saturation effect of nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond, which is a significant issue in the field of nonlinear fluorescence microscopy. The fluorescence reduction was observed under high-power laser excitation, resulting in increased nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altered spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. To extract the high spatial frequency information, we employed a differential excitation protocol. By modulating the excitation laser's power, we achieved a spatial resolution improvement of approximately 1.6 times, surpassing the confocal microscopy's capabilities. The simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing enables us to expect that this method can be easily adapted for enhancing the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling in solid-state systems, where defects are present.

original: When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the usual approach of employing individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer produces asymptotically unbiased inference. We construct a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We contrast our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration to reveal that only the bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a capstone for recent developmental efforts that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the bayesian modeling paradigm and provides a bridge across the two rich but disparate sub-fields.
polished: When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the traditional approach of using individual survey weights, constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities, to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that ensures unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We contrast our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, revealing that only the Bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real-data examples for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a culmination of recent developmental efforts that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling paradigm, providing a bridge across the two rich but disparate subfields.

original: Low-symmetry 2d materials---such as res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-iv monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, among others---have more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also take place due to low symmetry. The "beyond graphene: low-symmetry and anisotropic 2d materials" special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.
polished: Beyond the conventional honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides, a new class of low-symmetry 2D materials has emerged, featuring complex atomistic structures. This family of materials, which includes res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene, among others, exhibits reduced symmetries that give rise to a wide range of novel and inhomogeneous properties. These include ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity, as well as entirely new electronic, optical, valley, and spin responses. Furthermore, low-symmetry 2D materials can also exhibit novel topological electronic properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations. The "Beyond Graphene  Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic was curated to showcase the latest experimental and theoretical research on

original: Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups was studied using the kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, in contrast to low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be presented by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also made it possible to distinguish two processes of orientational relaxation: the first is due to rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with motion of the main chain segments.
polished: The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematogenic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were studied using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, in contrast to low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be presented by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also made it possible to distinguish two processes of orientational relaxation  the first is due to the rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with the motion of the main chain segments, which is a crucial aspect of the polymer's behavior in this regime.

original: Deep hashing methods have shown great retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. How to optimize discrete hash bits is always the focus in deep hashing methods. A common strategy in these methods is to adopt an activation function, e.g. $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm may make more and more hash bits stuck into the wrong saturated area of the activation functions and never escaped. We call this problem "dead bits problem~(dbp)". Besides, the existing quantization loss will aggravate dbp as well. In this paper, we propose a simple but effective gradient amplifier which acts before activation functions to alleviate dbp.
polished: Deep hashing methods have demonstrated remarkable retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits is the primary focus in deep hashing methods. A common approach in these methods is to adopt an activation function, such as the sigmoid or tanh function, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm may result in more and more hash bits being stuck in the saturated area of the activation functions and never escaping. We refer to this problem as the "dead bits problem." Moreover, the existing quantization loss will exacerbate this issue. In this paper, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier that acts before activation functions to alleviate this problem, thereby alleviating the "dead bits problem.

original: We study the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero su(2) triplet scalar whose existence is motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the standard model higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the lhc and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass less than $230\ \mathrm{gev}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence level.
polished: We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, whose existence is driven by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking processes. We examine both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the standard model Higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and by dark matter direct detection experiments, whereas the latter is constrained by existing multi-lepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass less than 230 GeV is excluded at 95% confidence level.

original: This paper shows that the eccentric debris rings seen around the stars fomalhaut and hd 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (sometimes referred to as "pericenter glow"). The standard scenario posits an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is increased to $e_f$ after the gas disc has dispersed by secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. In a minor modification of this scenario, narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, a primordial eccentricity could alternatively be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.
polished: This study reveals that the eccentric debris rings surrounding the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 exhibit a narrower width than anticipated within the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, often referred to as the "pericenter glow." The conventional scenario proposes an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis a, whose eccentricity is amplified to ef after the gas disc has dissipated due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width 2ae_f. In a minor modification of this scenario, narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.

original: An electron is usually considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, for its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? in one dimension (1d), the physics of interacting electrons is captured well at low energies by the tomonaga-luttinger-liquid (tll) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1d gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, together with the emergence of three additional 1d 'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1d inter-subband screening by over 45%.
polished: We propose that an electron, typically regarded as possessing a single type of kinetic energy, may actually exhibit multiple types of kinetic energy, owing to its spin and charge, or through the excitation of other electrons. In one dimension, the physics of interacting electrons is well-described by the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model at low energies. However, little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. In this work, we report on the measurement of many-body modes in one-dimensional gated wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. Our results reveal the presence of two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, corresponding to spin and charge excitations, as well as the emergence of three additional one-dimensional'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is modulated by varying the amount of one-dimensional inter-subband screening by over 45%.

original: $context$. The assembly history experienced by the milky way is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the $gaia$ mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. $aims$. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the milky way has experienced. $methods$. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by $gaia$ for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin we analysed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. $results$. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.
polished: The history of the Milky Way's assembly is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the Gaia mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the Milky Way has experienced. To achieve this, we combined the kinematic information provided by Gaia for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. Our results show that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

original: The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article illustrates intrinsic, an r package that implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. In detail, the methods included in this package are the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To allow these novel estimators to be easily accessible, the package contains a few high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models that fall into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category contains the two-nn and gride models. The functions dedicated to these two methods carry out inference under both the frequentist and bayesian frameworks. In the second category we find hidalgo, a bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient gibbs sampler is implemented.
polished: The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a crucial step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces intrinsic, an R package that offers state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. The package includes novel methods, specifically the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models, which are designed to be easily accessible through a set of high-level, user-friendly functions that leverage efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic dimension estimation encompasses two categories  homogeneous and heterogeneous models. The package provides functions for both homogeneous and heterogeneous methods, including the two-nn and gride models, which can be applied under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. Additionally, it features hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, with an efficient Gibbs sampler implementation.

original: Spintronic nanodevices have ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale that promises to enable spintronic reservoir computing (rc) system. Here two physical rc systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (msm) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (stnos) were proposed and modeled to process image classification task and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of msm and stno with current pulses stimulation, the handwritten digits recognition task domesticates that an rc system using one single msm has the outstanding performance on image classification. In addition, the complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be well solved by a physical rc system consisted of 24 stnos confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and narma10 tasks.
polished: Spintronics nanodevices have ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrent behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronics reservoir computing (RC) systems. Here, two physical RC systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOS) were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNOS with current pulse stimulation, our findings indicate that an RC system using a single MSM has outstanding performance on image classification tasks. Moreover, the complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be well solved by a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOS confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

original: Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms ranging from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of the overall traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer effect emerges in settings where there are few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect emerges when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items. Using simulations, we analyze how the strength of the effect changes with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also test our predictions experimentally in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings have important implications to understand the spread of misinformation.
polished: Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms, encompassing search engines and recommender systems. In this study, we uncover a counterintuitive consequence of popularity-based rankings  the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the more the collective traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer phenomenon arises in settings where there are limited distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that this effect emerges when individuals tend to click on top-ranked items and exhibit heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items. Through simulations, we examine how the strength of the effect varies with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also conduct an online experiment with human participants to test our predictions. Our findings have significant implications for understanding the dissemination of misinformation.

original: Weight pruning has been widely acknowledged as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (dnn), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most of the pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity which lead to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To solve the problem, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity that comprises pattern and connectivity sparsity, and becoming both highly accurate and hardware friendly. With carefully designed patterns, the proposed pruning unprecedentedly and consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability on different dnn structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework also achieves pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning and weight training simultaneously. Our approach on the new pattern-based sparsity naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient dnn execution on mobile platforms.
polished: Weight pruning, a widely recognized technique, has been employed as a straightforward and effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks, thereby accelerating performance on various platforms. However, most existing pruning techniques often involve a trade-off between model accuracy and regularity, leading to reduced inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration. To address this challenge, we introduce a novel sparsity dimension, pattern-based sparsity, which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity to achieve both high accuracy and hardware friendliness. By designing carefully crafted patterns, our approach consistently and unprecedentedly enhances accuracy and extracts better features from various deep neural network structures and datasets. Moreover, our pattern-aware pruning framework not only achieves pattern library extraction, pattern selection, and pattern pruning but also enables weight training, all simultaneously. The proposed pattern-based sparsity naturally integrates seamlessly with compiler optimization for highly efficient deep neural network execution on mobile platforms.

original: Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in less bias. We study this phenomenon in simulation studies. We study the effect of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that makes use of the increase in mrm following the 1990 clean air act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95\% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects along with no effect and small beneficial effects.
polished: A comprehensive difference-in-differences analysis with a carefully controlled control group that differs significantly from a treated group is susceptible to bias from historical events that have distinct effects on the groups. To mitigate this issue, we construct a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group, which may result in less bias. We investigate this phenomenon in simulation studies. We examine the effect of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that leverages the increase in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of MRM on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects, as well as small beneficial effects.

original: When constructing models to summarize clinical data to be used for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done by means of visual predictive checks (vpc), which consist of (1) several reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is straightforward to apply, in general. Here we consider the application of the method to time to event data and consider the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.
polished: When developing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate their ability to accurately reproduce the data. This can be achieved by means of visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve (1) multiple replications of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This approach is a straightforward method that can be applied in most cases, including the analysis of time-to-event data and considering the special case where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after event time.

original: Novel concepts, perspectives and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are shown. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can allow to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.
polished: The novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are showcased. We demonstrate how similar protocols, relying on repeated quantum measurements and dynamic decoupling control pulses, can enable us to  (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zero-phononics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will significantly enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thereby driving advances in quantum science and technology.

original: Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be so embarrassing. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster, you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death.see, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try and overcome it.to start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, "what if people think i'm awful and i'm an idiot?"
polished: The palms of your hands are sweaty, your heart is racing, and your stomach is in knots. You can't cry out for help, not only because your throat is too tight to breathe, but also because it would be an embarrassing ordeal. No, you're not being stalked by a monster; you're speaking in public, a fate that some people deem worse than death. When you're dead, you feel nothing; but at a podium, you feel stage fright. However, at some point, we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try and overcome it. To start, understanding what stage fright is, it's essential. As humans, social animals that we are, we're wired to worry about our reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, 'What if people think I'm awful and I'm an idiot?' It's natural to feel this way, but it's crucial to acknowledge that it's a normal feeling, and with practice, you can learn to overcome it.

original: I can't think of anyone who just has one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. [the way we work]around 15 percent of american workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. They're half-time, part-time, contract workers or temps. The term "side hustle" just seems to fit with this ethos where people are putting together a few different things to make a living.the word "side hustle" has its roots in popular african american newspapers. In the 1920s, these papers used the word "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they were using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work, too. A side hustle is a little different than a second job. A second job is about necessity.
polished: In a society where work-life balance is a pressing concern for many, it's refreshing to know that not everyone's life revolves around a single passion or profession. According to recent statistics, roughly 15% of American workers do not have traditional full-time jobs. Instead, they juggle multiple roles, juggling part-time, contract, and temp work to make ends meet. The concept of a "side hustle" has become increasingly popular in recent years, reflecting the entrepreneurial spirit of individuals who are piecing together various activities to create a fulfilling and sustainable income. The term "side hustle" has its roots in African American culture, dating back to the 1920s, when it was used in newspapers to describe a legitimate way to earn a living. By the 1950s, the term had evolved to encompass a broader range of activities, including legitimate work and entrepreneurial ventures. A side hustle is distinct from a second job, as it often involves a passion or interest outside of one's primary occupation.

original: Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by her.michelangelo said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was michelangelo's only tool. But living things are not chiseled. They grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information that's required for every other cell to function and to replicate.tools also have consequences. At least since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.
polished: The dichotomy between two twin domes, one crafted from thousands of steel components and the other from a single silk thread, highlights the fundamental contrast between synthetic and organic design approaches. One is imposed upon the environment, while the other creates it. Michelangelo once gazed upon raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be set free. The chisel was Michelangelo's only tool. However, living things do not conform to the chisel. They grow. At the most fundamental level, our cells carry all the information necessary for every other cell to function and replicate. Similarly, tools also have consequences. Since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production, leading to a profound impact on the way we approach design. This has resulted in a world where the boundaries between creator and creation are increasingly blurred, and the value of human craftsmanship is often overlooked.

original: Hello. My name is simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous when onstage, picture people in the audience naked? like it's this thing that's supposed to make you feel better. But i was thinking — picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. Like, we're working really hard on moving past stuff like that, so we need a new method of dealing with if you get nervous onstage. And i realized that what i'd really like is that i can look at you as much as you're looking at me — just to even things out a little bit. So if i had way more eyeballs, then we'd all be really comfortable, right?
polished: Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people often tell you that if you get nervous when you're on stage, you should picture people in the audience, as if you're naked. It's this feeling that's supposed to make you feel more at ease. However, I was thinking - picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels somewhat unusual and awkward. Like, we're working hard to move past these sorts of things, so we need a new approach to dealing with nervousness onstage. And I realized that what I'd really like is being able to look at you as much as you're looking at me - just to even things out a little bit. So, if I had way more eyes, then we'd all be incredibly comfortable, wouldn't we?

original: "to do two things at once is to do neither." it's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the roman writer publilius syrus, although you know how these things are, he probably never said it. What i'm interested in, though, is — is it true? i mean, it's obviously true for emailing at the dinner table or texting while driving or possibly for live tweeting at ted talk, as well. But i'd like to argue that for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once — or three or even four — is exactly what we should be aiming for.look no further than albert einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.
polished: The concept 'to do two things at once is to do neither' is a witty remark on multitasking, often attributed to Publilius Syrus, a Roman writer. While it's unclear whether he ever actually said this, it's an intriguing thought that has sparked debate. In reality, it's true that attempting to do multiple tasks simultaneously can be inefficient and lead to mistakes. For instance, trying to multitask during a dinner conversation or while driving can be hazardous. However, I'd argue that there are certain situations where doing multiple tasks at once can be beneficial. For instance, a person might need to research and prepare for a presentation while simultaneously conducting a meeting. In this case, multitasking can be a valuable skill. Albert Einstein, in his 1905 paper, demonstrated the importance of multitasking in his scientific work. He published four groundbreaking papers that year, showcasing his ability to work on multiple projects simultaneously. His approach to multitasking was a key factor in his success, and it's a valuable lesson for anyone looking to achieve their goals.

original: I know this is going to sound strange, but i think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, i grew up in bethlehem, pennsylvania, the home of bethlehem steel. My father was an engineer, and when i was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home, when i was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build ... A robot.a robot.
polished: I must confess that my notion may seem unconventional, but I firmly believe that robots can serve as an inspiration to make us better humans. As a native of Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the birthplace of Bethlehem Steel, I grew up surrounded by the spirit of innovation and ingenuity. My father, an engineer, instilled in me a deep appreciation for the intricacies of how things work. We spent countless hours together, constructing models of rockets and slot cars, and I still cherish the memories of those moments. The go-kart we built together is a testament to the power of imagination and creativity. In this particular instance, I'm proud to share with you a photo of myself behind the wheel, accompanied by my sister and my childhood best friend. It was a memorable day, and one that I will always treasure. As I was around 10 years old, my father sat us down at the dinner table, he revealed to us that our next project would be the creation of a robot - a robot. It was an announcement that I will never forget, and it marked the beginning of a journey that would take me

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how i impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.
polished: Sustainability represents the essence of what, where, and how seafood is caught. The who and the why behind my dinner choices are what's most important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices, and how I impact them. I want to know how they impact me, and why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the ocean's bounty for their very existence. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perspective on seafood from a mere commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows us to celebrate the seafood we're fortunate to enjoy, while also recognizing the importance of preserving the ocean's resources for future generations. This holistic approach is what we call restorative seafood, where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, and restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

original: The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of charles dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of dickens's writing that make it so special?dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.
polished: The starving orphan, seeking a second helping of gruel, is a poignant reminder of the struggles of the Victorian era. The spinster, wasting away in her tattered wedding dress, is a poignant portrayal of the fragility of life. The stone-hearted miser, plagued by the ghost of Christmas past, is a haunting reflection of the consequences of one's actions. Over a century after his death, these characters remain recognizable figures from the work of Charles Dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective, "Dickensian". But what are the features of Dickens's writing that make it so special? His fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.

original: Shah rukh khan: courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the biggest achievers have in common. These are those brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What looks to us an unconquerable sea, to our next speaker is an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. So let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, bhakti sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti sharma. polished:
Shah Rukh Khan's mantra of success  courage, unwavering determination, and an unrelenting vision. These are the hallmarks of the most accomplished individuals, whose unyielding spirits refuse to accept defeat. To them, seemingly insurmountable challenges are merely a canvas waiting to be conquered. Bhakti Sharma  Imagine a two-and-a-half-year-old child, carefree and full of wonder, riding pillion on a moped behind her mother on a sweltering summer afternoon in Rajasthan, with no notion of the journey's destination. And just 20 minutes later, that same child finds herself fully immersed in the cool waters of a pool, as if she had always been meant to be there.

original: I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at oxford now, that we think is going to change the way that computer games and hollywood movies are being made. This groundbreaking technology involves simulating humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body.
